ghostPost.plaintext:
Karl Fogel [https://duckduckgo.com/?q=karl+fogel] has been an open source
developer, author, project manager, and specialist in collaborative development
techniques since 1992.

In 1995, he and Jim Blandy co-founded Cyclic Software, the first company
offering commercial support for CVS, the free software version control system;
in 1997 he added support for anonymous read-only repository access to CVS. In
1999 he wrote Open Source Development With CVS [http://cvsbook.red-bean.com/] 
(Coriolis OpenPress). From 2000-2006, he worked for CollabNet, Inc
[http://collab.net/] as a founding developer in the Subversion
[http://subversion.apache.org/] project. In 2005 he wrote Producing Open Source
Software: How to Run a Successful Free Software Project
[http://producingoss.com/] (O'Reilly Media).

He has since been an open source specialist at Google [http://google.com/], at 
Canonical Ltd [http://canonical.com/] (where he helped release the Launchpad.net
[http://launchpad.net/] code), at O'Reilly Media [http://oreilly.com/], and at 
Code for America [http://codeforamerica.org/] / Civic Commons
[http://civiccommons.org/], where he worked with non-profits and government
agencies to release and manage open civic technology projects.  Karl has also
been a board member at the Open Source Initiative [http://opensource.org/], an 
Open Internet Tools Project Fellow [http://openitp.org/] at the New America
Foundation [http://newamerica.net/], and is a member of the Apache Software
Foundation [http://apache.org/].

In addition to his books, some of his articles on collaborative development are:
“Teams and Tools
[https://www.red-bean.com/kfogel/beautiful-teams/bt-chapter-21.html]”, “
Dissecting The Myth That Open Source Software Is Not Commercial
[http://blog.ieeesoftware.org/2016/04/dissecting-myth-that-open-source.html]”, “
What's the Return on Investment for Open?
[http://civiccommons.org/2010/10/roi-of-open/]”, “What Is Free Software?”, “
Open
source mistakes for enterprise newcomers
[https://www.oreilly.com/ideas/open-source-mistakes-for-enterprise-newcomers]”
(with James Vasile), and “Be Open from Day One, not Day N
[http://civiccommons.org/2011/01/be-open-from-day-one/]”.

Further information can be found in his GitHub
[https://github.com/kfogel?tab=activity], Twitter [https://twitter.com/kfogel],
and Identi.ca [https://identi.ca/kfogel] accounts, among other places.

Karl Fogel has been an open source developer, author, project manager, and specialist in collaborative development techniques since 1992.

In 1995, he and Jim Blandy co-founded Cyclic Software, the first company offering commercial support for CVS, the free software version control system; in 1997 he added support for anonymous read-only repository access to CVS. In 1999 he wrote Open Source Development With CVS (Coriolis OpenPress). From 2000-2006, he worked for CollabNet, Inc as a founding developer in the Subversion project. In 2005 he wrote Producing Open Source Software: How to Run a Successful Free Software Project (O'Reilly Media).

He has since been an open source specialist at Google, at Canonical Ltd (where he helped release the Launchpad.net code), at O'Reilly Media, and at Code for America / Civic Commons, where he worked with non-profits and government agencies to release and manage open civic technology projects.  Karl has also been a board member at the Open Source Initiative, an Open Internet Tools Project Fellow at the New America Foundation, and is a member of the Apache Software Foundation.

In addition to his books, some of his articles on collaborative development are: “Teams and Tools”, “Dissecting The Myth That Open Source Software Is Not Commercial”, “What's the Return on Investment for Open?”, “What Is Free Software?”, “Open source mistakes for enterprise newcomers” (with James Vasile), and “Be Open from Day One, not Day N”.

Further information can be found in his GitHub, Twitter, and Identi.ca accounts, among other places.
